question: How might the post-election interest among some American women in adopting South Korea‚Äôs 4B movement‚Äîrejecting dating, sex, marriage, and childbirth with men‚Äîshape U.S. conversations about gender, politics, and personal autonomy, and what social or political consequences could follow?

content.source_1:
In the hours and days since it became clear that Donald Trump would be re-elected president of the United States, there‚Äôs been asurge of interestin the US for 4B.

Young liberal women across TikTok and Instagram are discussing and sharing information about the South Korean feminist movement, in which straight women refuse to marry, have children, date or have sex with men.

Related articleAfter two presidential losses, women wonder what it will take to shatter the glass ceiling

These women say they are enraged and fed up after a majority of their male counterparts voted for a candidate who was found liable forsexual abuseand whose appointment of three conservative Supreme Court justicesled to the overturningof nationalabortion rightsprotections.

In response, they say they‚Äôre swearing off men ‚Äî and they‚Äôre encouraging others around the country to join them.

‚ÄúWe have pandered and begged for men‚Äôs safety and done all the things that we were supposed to, and they still hate us,‚Äù Ashli Pollard, a 36-year-old in St. Louis, told CNN.

‚ÄúSo if you‚Äôre going to hate us, then we‚Äôre going to do what we want.‚Äù

4B is a shorthand for the four Korean words bihon, bichulsan, biyeonae and bisekseu, which translate to no marriage, no childbirth, no dating and no sex with men.

The 4B movement emerged in South Korea around 2015 or 2016, per Ju Hui Judy Han, an assistant professor in gender studies at the University of California, Los Angeles. Mostly popular among young women in their 20s, she described it as a fringe offshoot of #MeToo and other feminist movements that arose in response to stark gender inequality in the country.

In 2016, a woman wasbrutally killednear a Seoul subway station ‚Äî the perpetratorreportedly saidhe killed her because he felt ignored by women. The incident prompted a national reckoning around how women are treated in the country, expanding to include conversations around femicide,revenge pornanddigital sex crimes.

Feminism and the gender divide have beenhot button issuesin South Korea. Women in the country are paid aboutone-third lessthan men, according todatafrom the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development ‚Äî the highest wage gap among OECD nations. And despite being one of the world‚Äôs most advanced economies, women there arescarcelyrepresented in senior and managerial roles.

The 4B movement was decentralized and existed in various iterations online and offline, making it difficult to assess its true size and scale. Over the years, the movement has diminished and splintered over disagreements about the role of queer and trans women, according to Han. But she says 4B and other South Korean feminist movements drew attention to gender inequality in the country and emphasized collective action.

Related articleEscape the corset: How South Koreans are pushing back against beauty standards

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a very widespread movement, but the sentiments behind it I think a lot of people empathize with,‚Äù Han says.

‚ÄúWhen there is such widespread violence against women, there is such systemic discrimination and inequality, when there‚Äôs so much that make marriage, childbirth and child rearing ‚Ä¶  difficult, why and how could anyone imagine getting married and giving birth?‚Äù

Though South Korea‚Äôs 4B movement mostly faded from media headlines in recent years, the US election has renewed interest.

‚ÄúA lot of us ‚Äî straight or not, queer or not, whether you‚Äôre in a marriage or not ‚Äî are going to be in the same boat, dealing with an oppressive and violent institutions,‚Äù Han says. ‚ÄúAnd we see each other.‚Äù

It‚Äôs far too early to tell whether the 4B movement might seriously catch on in the US. But so far, at least, it‚Äôs generated a lot of online discussion among young women.

Some women are discovering the movement anew and are vowing to join. Others who are already married or partnered up say they plan to protest in other ways, such as boycotting male-owned businesses or refusing to do emotional labor for men.

Pollard says she learned about South Korea‚Äôs 4B movement a few years ago, inspiring her to ‚Äúexamine what a life looks like without centering men so deeply.‚Äù Since 2022, she says she hasn‚Äôt dated or slept with men and has realized that she‚Äôs better off on her own. She has the resources to support herself without marriage, and she plans to have a child alone.

Her decision to disengage from men wasn‚Äôt necessarily an act of vengeance, she says. Rather, it was about putting herself first. Now that other women around the country have taken an interest in 4B, she says she wants them to realize that they have other options.

‚ÄúYou push people far enough and they‚Äôre done,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúHow will that affect politics? We‚Äôll see ‚Ä¶ but I think that women and their joy is going to be something that can‚Äôt really be overlooked anymore. Women are choosing themselves in droves.‚Äù

Alexa Vargas, a 26-year-old from Boston, says she stopped engaging with men a few years ago after a series of unhealthy relationships that included abuse and assault, and it wasn‚Äôt until earlier this year that she realized there was a movement and language that aligned with her actions. Though she says that ‚Äúmen need a wake-up call,‚Äù her decision is more about herself and other women.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if men are going to change their ways. I don‚Äôt know how this is going to pan out,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúMy goal in life and in this movement is to protect young women and girls.‚Äù

Women who have been talking about 4B online say the way some men have responded to their posts are already proving their point.

Abby K.,a 27-year-old from Florida,recently broke up with her boyfriend over dismissive comments he made about Trump‚Äôs history of sexual abuse. When she posted a video about that and her decision to join the 4B movement, she says men flooded her DMs with death threats and hateful comments about her appearance.

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt exactly entice you to re-enter the dating pool,‚Äù she adds.

In Han‚Äôs view, the 4B movement is unlikely to become mainstream in the US.

She says it relies too heavily on the gender binary and that those inspired to join it as a result of the election are overlooking the fact that plenty of women voted for Trump, too. (Though Vice President Kamala Harris maintained an edge with women,exit pollsindicate that her lead was smaller than President Joe Biden‚Äôs or former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton‚Äôs during their respective presidential campaigns.)

Hadia Khanani, a 24-year-old from Florida, also has reservations about 4B in the US. Though she hasn‚Äôt engaged with men romantically for several years in an effort to prioritize herself, she wants women to dig deeper and examine their own role in upholding patriarchy. She also worries about the consequences of further isolating men.

‚ÄúThe conversation online has been centered around sleeping with men and dating men, obviously to protect yourself, but I just feel like misogyny and patriarchy is much deeper than that,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI think a lot of it is rooted in the way that men are raised in society.‚Äù

Even if large numbers of women don‚Äôt adopt the strict tenets of 4B, those who are taking part for now hope the recent conversations around it lead women to think about themselves and their circumstances differently.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt ever expect everyone in America to hold hands and agree not to date men,‚Äù Abby K. says. ‚ÄúI could definitely see it fueling change in some way.‚Äù

Han predicts that American interest in the 4B movement will subside quickly. Still, she hopes that the recent discourse around it will help women understand that they aren‚Äôt alone in their struggles and build solidarity with others around the world.

‚ÄúI think a lot of American women are ‚Ä¶ trying to find ways to seek empowerment and find a way to survive,‚Äù Han says. ‚ÄúAnd I hope what they find is not necessarily a particular movement like the 4B movement, but a recognition that struggles for reproductive justice and gender equality are certainly not just American concerns.‚Äù

CNN‚Äôs Leda Joy Abkenari contributed to this report.
content.source_2:
FollowingDonald Trump‚Äôs election victory, a South Korean feminist movement called the ‚Äú4B Movement‚Äù is resonating with Americanwomen on TikTok. The movement‚Äôs principles, which include rejecting dating, marriage, sex and childbirth with men, have sparked conversations about gender dynamics in the U.S. amid concerns about women‚Äôs rights.

Inspired by years of activism in South Korea, the‚Äú4B Movement‚Äù‚Äî shorthand for the ‚ÄúFour Nos‚Äù ‚Äî advocates for complete independence from men as a protest against societal expectations.

Since Trump‚Äôs 2024 victory, many women in the U.S. have adopted these ideals. Many cite a sense of solidarity and frustration with what they see as setbacks to women‚Äôs rights under his leadership.

Download the SAN app today to stay up-to-date with Unbiased. Straight Facts‚Ñ¢.

OnTikTok, hashtags like #4BMovement and #4BNos have gathered millions of views. Many women are sharing their personal stories and decisions to ‚Äúopt-out‚Äù of relationships with men.

Influential users whose videos on the topic have gone viral, say the movement provides a sense of control in an environment where they feel their rights are increasingly under threat.

The ‚Äú4B Movement‚Äù emerged inSouth Koreaas a reaction to social issues such as the country‚Äôs gender wage gap, high rates of workplace harassment and limited protections for women. In recent years, it has influenced everything from birth rates to marriage trends. Advocates say opting out of traditional roles is a form of resistance to gender inequality.

Critics of the movement argue that it could deepen social divisions. They‚Äôve called it an ‚Äúextreme response‚Äù that risks fueling a so-called ‚Äúgender war.‚Äù

Yet for supporters, the decision to join 4B isn‚Äôt simply aTikTok trend, it‚Äôs a call for meaningful change and a rejection of societal pressures.

While it‚Äôs unclear if the 4B Movement will have lasting effects in the U.S., it‚Äôs clear the ideas it represents are resonating with many women post-election. As more women turn to social media to share their views, the movement‚Äôs popularity shows no signs of slowing down.

FOR CENTURIES, IT HAS BEEN PERFORMED ON STAGE AND SHOWN ON FILM‚Ä¶ STUDIED IN SCHOOLS AND GILDED AS ONE OF THE EARLIEST NARRATIVES ON FEMALE EMPOWERMENT.

NOW‚Ä¶ A NEW MOVEMENT IS MAKING IT OVER TO THE STATES FROM SOUTH KOREA‚Ä¶ INSPIRED BY THIS SAME STORY.

‚ÄúYou will never control your own bodies, you will never be the leader of a global empire. Not gonna happen sweetie. Your body, our choice‚Äù

‚ÄúI feel like I‚Äôm in a different world today‚Ä¶ this is so heartbreaking..

A SIGNIFICANT PORTION OF AMERICAN WOMEN ARE NOT HAPPY WITH THE RESULTS OF THE 2024 ELECTION‚Ä¶ AND UNCERTAIN OF WHAT IT MEANS FOR THEIR FUTURE. IN PROTEST‚Ä¶ THEY ARE JOINING A MOVEMENT.

IT‚ÄôS CALLED THE ‚Äú4B MOVEMENT‚Äù‚Ä¶ IT BEGAN IN SOUTH KOREA AND ENCOURAGES WOMEN TO ‚ÄúOPT OUT‚Äù OF MEN ENTIRELY.

ITS FOUR PRINCIPLES ARE NO DATING, NO MARRIAGE, NO SEXUAL RELATIONSHIPS, AND NO CHILDBIRTH WITH MEN. AND THEY IDEA IS GAINING TRACTION ON SOCIAL MEDIA.

SEVERAL TIKTOK USERS ARE COMMITTING TO THE PLEDGE, AND ENCOURAGING OTHER WOMEN TO DO THE SAME. SOME ARE ALSO SHAVING THEIR HEADS IN PROTEST. VIDEOS ON THE MOVEMENT HAVE BEEN VIEWED MILLIONS OF TIMES‚Ä¶ BUT IT REMAINS TO BE SEEN IF THIS COULD SNOWBALL INTO AFFECTING THE AMERICAN BIRTH RATE.

THE 4B MOVEMENT HAS TAPPED INTO FRUSTRATIONS THAT ARE NOT UNIQUE TO SOUTH KOREA. WOMEN IN BOTH COUNTRIES REPORT FACING A GENDER WAGE GAP, WORKPLACE HARASSMENT, AND DISCRIMINATION.

IN FACT, SOUTH KOREA HAS ONE OF THE LARGEST GENDER WAGE GAPS AMONG DEVELOPED NATIONS, AND MANY 4B ADVOCATES VIEW OPTING OUT OF TRADITIONAL RELATIONSHIPS WITH MEN AS A WAY TO REJECT A SYSTEM THEY FEEL OPPRESSES THEM.

IN SOUTH KOREA‚Ä¶ THE MOVEMENT HAS BEEN CREDITED WITH REDUCING BIRTH RATES AND CHALLENGING TRADITIONAL FAMILY STRUCTURES. CRITICS ARGUE THAT IT COULD CONTRIBUTE TO A ‚ÄúGENDER WAR,‚Äù BUT SUPPORTERS SAY IT‚ÄôS ABOUT FINDING SAFETY AND INDEPENDENCE.

content.source_3:
Liberal women are withholding sex from men and shaving their heads to protest President-elect Donald Trump‚Äôs landslide victory over Kamala Harris.

The demonstration was inspired by South Korea‚Äôs ‚Äú4B‚Äù movement against gender-based violence where some women in that country have vowed to follow the four ‚Äúno‚Äôs‚Äù ‚Äî no sex, no dating or marriage and no having children with men.

The trend took off in the US on TikTok after Trump‚Äôs win Tuesday, with many women posting about their refusal to engage with men romantically or sexually over the next four years, citing dwindling abortion access across the nation and an increase in young male Republican voters.

‚ÄúAs a woman, my bodily autonomy matters, and this is my way to exercise sovereignty over that,‚Äùsaid a TikTokker, who encouraged other women to ‚Äúdelete their dating apps‚Äù in solidarity.

‚ÄúIf you need someone to cuddle or give you a kiss, I bet you one of your girlfriends would do it, and you don‚Äôt even need to be gay. It‚Äôs OK to have a lot of platonic love for the next four years,‚Äù she said.

Other users have taken to the platform toencourage womento ‚Äútake it a step further‚Äù and ‚Äúcollectively get hysterectomies,‚Äù while some said they are‚Äúbreaking up with their Republican boyfriends‚Äùin the wake of the election.

‚ÄúF‚Äìk being skinny, f‚Äìk being hot, f‚Äìk being all the things that the patriarchy wants us to be, ‚Äôcause clearly they don‚Äôt give a s‚Äìt about us,‚Äù said one user who began haphazardly shaving her full head of hair on camera.

‚ÄúStop dating men, stop having sex with men, stop talking to men, divorce your husbands, leave your f‚Äìking boyfriends, leave them,‚Äù she said.

Exit polls support¬†the premise that young men have become overwhelmingly conservative in the past four years ‚Äî while women ages 18 to 29 went overwhelmingly left, in part because of concerns over reproductive rights.

Young women supported Harris over Trump by 18 points, while young men backed the president-elect by 14 points,according to Tufts University Tisch College research.

In South Korea, the ‚Äú4B‚Äù movement ‚Äî which stands for the four vows that begin with ‚Äúbi‚Äù (‚Äúno‚Äù in English) ‚Äî was an offshoot of national protests against the ‚Äúspycam‚Äù epidemic, where women were often unknowingly filmed during sex or while in the bathroom without their consent.

South Korean leaders became worried over the ‚Äú4B‚Äù movement when it allegedly began having an effect on the country‚Äôs birth rates after launching in 2017 and picking up momentum in 2019.

In 2021, the country‚Äôs president, Yoon Suk-yeo, said feminist movements were ‚Äúblocking healthy relationships‚Äù between men and women in the nation,Chosun reported.

For three years in a row, the country has recorded the¬†lowest fertility rate¬†in the world, with women of reproductive age having less than one child on average, according to the New York Times.

In the US, only 25% of men between the ages of 18 and 29 identify as politically liberal, while 40% of women in the same age group do,according to a recent Gallup poll.

Experts say the US political gender divide has led to Gen Z dating woes, as many young men embrace the ideologies of popular podcasters such as Joe Rogan, the Nelk Boys, and Adin Ross ‚Äî all of whom were thanked for helping to get the president-elect to victory by UFC CEO Dana White during Trump‚Äôs Wednesday victory speech at Mar-a-Lago.

Some people have opposed the movement, poking fun at those who have modified their appearances in solidarity and called for extreme measures of divorce.

‚Äù ‚ÄòJoin the Republican Party, keep your hair‚Äô: Never thought I‚Äôd have to say that,‚Äùone user saidin reaction to the movement.
